10.21.text:
My name is Caroline Nokes and I am Member
of Parliament for Romsey and Southampton North

13.51.text:
and also a member of the Speaker’s Advisory
Committee on Works of Art, which I was going

18.03.text:
to say I have done for five years since I
was elected but that would be actually false.

22.44.text:
One of the first things that struck me when
I was asked to join the committee was that

27.00.text:
it took a while after the general election
to reconstitute the committee. That is not

31.87.text:
a failure on anyone’s part, it’s just
a happening of circumstance in this place.

36.65.text:
But something that many of us are very concerned
about post 2015 is that we have to make sure

42.20.text:
that the committee is reconstituted as swiftly
as possible so that we can crack on with some

46.16.text:
of the excellent work that has already been
done.

50.39.text:
International Women’s Day is an important
moment to reflect on women’s achievements

55.27.text:
and the issues which affect women. This year,
as part of Parliament’s events, we have

60.10.text:
the ‘Women in Parliament: Works from the
Parliamentary Art Collection’ exhibition

64.14.text:
on display. This exhibition documents women’s
engagement with – and I think it’s important

69.38.text:
to emphasise that because obviously women
had an impact on this place long before they

74.02.text:
were ever elected - so it’s their engagement
with and achievements in Parliament since

78.31.text:
the 1780s. Today we are also very pleased
to be launching the associated publication

84.03.text:
– I have one of these to wave at you which
makes me feel slightly like an air hostess

87.07.text:
– and before you all leave they are on the
tables at either side of the room. It documents

93.87.text:
the collection and is absolutely fascinating
to read and perhaps look at the works of art

100.84.text:
in conjunction with it.
I would like to take this opportunity to thank

104.70.text:
Oonagh Gay of the House of Commons Library
and Mari Takayanagi of the Parliamentary Archives

112.45.text:
– and of course Melanie Unwin who is from
the Curator’s Office and who has been a

116.95.text:
fantastic support and I would like to say
real driving force to our commitment to get

122.97.text:
more women represented in the collection.
I very much enjoyed looking at the exhibition

128.73.text:
and it has been very inspiring and affirming
to see the many portraits of past women MPs

134.81.text:
and to reflect on their achievements and how
they have changed our society. We do have

140.18.text:
some obvious gaps in our collection and those
have been caused by nothing more sinister

144.86.text:
than historic circumstance. But we are committed
to trying to find portraiture of the missing

152.11.text:
and significant women to fill those gaps and
it is something that I think is critically

157.54.text:
important that we are brave enough to embrace
publicity around the women’s collection

163.00.text:
and say actually, look, there are some gaps,
we would love to find portraits of significant

169.16.text:
women that we simply don’t have in the collection
and so while sometimes Members are a little

174.76.text:
reluctant to talk about art in this place
and particularly sometimes the media try and

181.03.text:
pick holes in our commitment to what I think
from a historic perspective is so important

186.44.text:
to be brave enough to talk about it, to promote
it and hopefully to highlight to those people

191.58.text:
who might know where some of the hidden women
are, to come forward and let us know.

198.04.text:
It is perhaps then appropriate that the subject
of this evening’s lecture is Irene Ward.

202.79.text:
A Member of Parliament who contested her first
election in 1924 when she was still too young

209.28.text:
to vote for herself and she subsequently served
as an MP for nearly 38 years. Ward is one

216.90.text:
of the significant women of whom there is
no known portrait, but pleased be assured

220.81.text:
we keep searching. But before we hear more
about Irene Ward, I am delighted to introduce

227.20.text:
our first speaker this evening, Eleanor Laing
MP. Eleanor was appointed Deputy Speaker,

233.28.text:
officially the first Deputy Chairman of Ways
and Means in 2013 and she is only the sixth

239.01.text:
woman to have ever held that position. We
are delighted that she has agreed to give

244.32.text:
the introductory talk to this year’s lecture.
Eleanor Laing

256.63.text:
Thank you very much, Caroline and good evening
ladies and gentlemen. It is wonderful to be

263.44.text:
here talking about something as inspiring
as the art collection, rather than what is

270.86.text:
going to be in our party manifesto over the
next few months. Parliament is a wonderful

279.32.text:
place. It isn’t only about politics and
policies and arguments and speeches and rhetoric.

287.88.text:
It is also the best institution that our country
has, I would argue, that the world has ever

301.68.text:
known. This Parliament here at Westminster
that has been here in one form or another

315.87.text:
The historical 
anniversaries committee celebrated in this

330.29.text:
very room the 750th anniversary of the Simon
de Montfort Parliament just a few weeks ago

337.48.text:
and a few weeks after that, leading up to
June 2015 we will be celebrating the 800th

345.84.text:
anniversary of Magna Carta. It all comes together
celebrating freedom and democracy and I honestly

355.57.text:
believe that our iconic Parliament building
here is an internationally renowned symbol

364.70.text:
of that freedom and democracy that is so important
to us and that around the world today we see

373.12.text:
in countries that don’t have freedom and
don’t have democracy, how much help they

378.26.text:
need from us and how much they look to us
as one of the leaders of the free world to

387.32.text:
keep reminding people how important it is
to uphold democracy. In doing so, I think

394.95.text:
it is terribly important that we don’t only
look at the political events and issues that

402.92.text:
are before us today in 2015. It is terribly
important that we appreciate sometimes in

410.21.text:
some form or another the linear history of
which we are part. And I do believe that the

421.15.text:
Women in Parliament Parliamentary Art Collection
and all that it stands for and all that we

426.22.text:
have been talking about today is a very important
part of that historical progression and also

436.28.text:
a very important part of preserving people’s
understanding of where we came from and where

442.24.text:
we’re going to, because unless you know
where we came from, you cannot guide where

447.85.text:
we are going to. And I’m sorry to hear that
there aren’t portraits of Irene Ward – I’m

454.27.text:
sure you’ll find one somewhere now that
the word has gone out. But nowadays we are

459.90.text:
much better at that and the art committee
has been brilliant at it. On the front place

467.42.text:
of this magazine you see the great new portrait
of my colleague, the other Deputy Speaker,

478.62.text:
Dawn Primarolo. It is a brilliant portrait
which was also unveiled in this very room

485.70.text:
not long ago. She’s actually much prettier
than that and she does sometimes smile. I

490.62.text:
know it’s thought when you’re Deputy Speaker
and in the chair and being stern and calling

495.98.text:
‘Order! Order!’ and keeping people in
order and under control that smiling is not

503.52.text:
the order of the day, so that’s Dawn looking
very professional indeed. But she does sometimes

509.53.text:
smile as well. The important thing is that
we celebrate and remember people who represent

518.66.text:
different parts of our democracy and in considering
women in Parliament there are always certain

528.73.text:
questions that I am asked and one of them
is “who is your role model?” And of course,

537.29.text:
in my case, there is a terribly simple answer
to that which is terribly obvious. So this

543.37.text:
evening I am not going to give you the obvious
answer (the obvious answer is Margaret Thatcher)

548.25.text:
there are lots and lots of portraits of Margaret
Thatcher and lots of books about Margaret

551.90.text:
Thatcher and she was a wonderful reformer
and a fantastic role model for women. I’m

560.07.text:
sorry am I being heckled there? Well I don’t
expect everybody to agree with me but I’m

571.56.text:
sorry Madam but I’ll choose my role models
and you can choose yours! The great thing

580.07.text:
that Margaret Thatcher did is that she made
it impossible for people to say to women of

586.04.text:
my generation and those coming afterwards
“you can’t do it because you’re a woman.”

592.19.text:
And that’s what people said, I remember
at school being asked at the stage my son

597.40.text:
is now in choosing his GCSEs “what do you
want to be” and I said I had an interest

604.03.text:
in politics and they said “oh yes, there
there, do you want to be a doctor or a layer

608.15.text:
or a teacher?” and nobody took it seriously
and after Margaret Thatcher and others of

614.46.text:
her generation, other brilliant women like
Shirley Williams and Barbara Castle and others

620.64.text:
who are still here in Parliament who are great
role models to all of us, nobody can say “you

628.04.text: can’t do it because you’re a woman”.

630.79.text:
But I wanted to tell you about my real role
model because when I was a very little girl,

639.66.text:
our Member of Parliament at home in East Renfrewshire
which is to the West of Glasgow in the West

645.18.text:
coast of Scotland, was Betty Harvey Anderson.
Now this is a genuine question: who has heard

651.81.text:
of Betty Harvey Anderson? Hands up. Just a
few. Well Betty Harvey Anderson was the MP

660.91.text:
for East Renfrewshire for 20 years or so and
I knew her because I had been introduced to

668.22.text:
her by my father and she came to our house
so I knew what an MP was when I was 10 years

675.28.text:
old. I knew what an MP was and it was a lady
with her grey hair up in a bun who spoke to

681.10.text:
me in a very similar way to the way my headmistress
at school spoke to me. So I knew that that’s

687.27.text:
what an MP was – to me an MP was not a man
in a three piece suit who said “there there

693.62.text:
dear”, it was a lady who was very determined
and sure of herself. Betty Harvey Anderson

700.69.text:
ought to be better remembered because she
was the first woman ever to sit in the Speaker’s

708.15.text:
chair. She was the first Deputy Speaker of
the House of Commons to be a woman. When she

716.55.text:
was appointed Deputy Speaker, the House addressed
her as ‘Mr Deputy Speaker’ because it

724.62.text:
didn’t occur to them to call her Madam Deputy
Speaker because that had never been done before

728.42.text:
and you didn’t do things that hadn’t been
done before, so they called her Mr Deputy

733.29.text:
Speaker. I think eventually they called her
Madam Deputy Speaker. She was my role model

741.97.text:
and I believe it’s terribly important that
we tell future generations that women take

750.23.text:
their part in the system of freedom and democracy
in our free country every bit as men do and

759.51.text:
because there are more role models in history
who happen to be men makes it all the more

764.86.text:
important that the work that we are doing
in a meeting like this tonight highlights

771.25.text: the role that women play here in Parliament.

776.03.text:
The second question I am always asked is “Has
Parliament changed? “Is it different because

782.79.text:
there are more women?” and the answer is
“Yes”. I have been a Member of Parliament

788.89.text:
for 18 years so I came in in 1997 when we
had that huge influx of women and that made

796.42.text:
a big difference. I worked here for a cabinet
minister before I was elected so I know how

803.93.text:
this place felt when there were very few women
around and I know how it feels now that there

812.13.text:
is a critical mass of women. Of course we
need more and we are all working towards that,

818.62.text:
always. Most of us here in Parliament have
been working very hard for decades to try

824.98.text:
to have more women elected on all political
fronts. But there is a big difference, because

833.53.text:
while you only have a handful of women, then
making the woman’s voice heard is very much

841.84.text:
more difficult and the culture of the place
is different when there aren’t a significant

848.54.text:
number of women. Now it depends on what you
call a significant number. I have never been

853.37.text:
particularly bothered that there should be
50% but at that moment we are still only at

859.13.text:
about 20%. If we can increase the number of
women in Parliament to around 30% it stops

866.76.text:
being an issue because then there are enough
women to do all of the jobs that need to be

874.01.text:
I can remember on International Women’s
Day about 15 years ago, we had a debate of

881.64.text:
course on women’s issues. Now we have to
fight for them in front of the backbench business

887.79.text:
committee but over these last five years we
have succeeded in front of the backbench business

892.25.text:
committee in obtaining a debate on women on
or near International Women’s Day. But 15

900.91.text:
years ago we had a debate on International
Women’s Day and on the then government side

911.01.text:
there was a significant number of women – not
huge – but significant. And I was on the

916.69.text:
opposition side, along with my then colleague,
Julie Kirkbride. And there was just two of

923.18.text:
us and someone at the Despatch Box. There
were just two of us. So we started off sitting

932.05.text:
on the third and fourth row above the gangway
and then after about half an hour one of us

938.82.text:
moved to another position and then the other
moved to a different position and we spent

943.56.text:
the whole afternoon moving round the chamber
so that as we were caught on camera it would

949.04.text:
look as if there were more of us – I kid
you not! What an awful thing to have to resort

958.98.text:
to, actually moving round the chamber to make
it look as though there were more of you.

963.18.text:
I was ashamed back then that there weren’t
more people, both men and women supporting

970.87.text:
But things have changed very significantly
these last 18 years. Very significantly and

977.72.text:
the current generation of men no longer laugh
at a debate on International Women’s Day.

986.55.text:
And it is terribly important that we take
forward the place of women in our national

994.02.text:
life and in our democratic system. Women from
all parts of the political spectrum because

1002.64.text:
it simply isn’t fair to shout down any person
because of their beliefs of what they stand

1010.69.text:
for or what they say. And if you jeer at Margaret
Thatcher, I wouldn’t have people jeer at

1017.56.text:
Nelson Mandela or at Harold Wilson or at anyone
else with whom I disagree because the reason

1023.61.text:
for standing here and the reason for being
here in a free and democratic system is that

1028.22.text:
everyone has the right of free speech to stand
up for what they believe in and then we bring

1034.32.text:
these beliefs and ideas to Parliament, we
discuss them, we argue about them, we vote

1039.22.text:
upon them, we make laws and that’s what
democracy is all about. And the more that

1045.06.text:
we have women involved in our free democratic
system, the better that system will be. And

1052.05.text:
I believe that women and the role of women
should be promoted in every way possible.

1060.31.text:
And Mary Branson’s wonderful sculpture which
I gather you have had a very good presentation

1073.15.text:
- isn’t it wonderful? And it’s going to
have a very prominent place in the Houses

1081.03.text:
of Parliament. It’s going to have a prominent
place and every time people look at it, we

1087.60.text:
will remember that women fought to give us
the freedom of speech, the vote and the right

1095.77.text:
to sit in this wonderful Parliament that represents
freedom and let us go on promoting the role

1105.69.text:
of women and all that we can do for freedom
and democracy. Thank you.

1123.16.text:
I’d just like to say a huge thank you to
Eleanor for coming along this evening, wonderful

1135.55.text:
words and for somebody like me who really
is just starting out in their parliamentary

1140.61.text:
career – you can say that in this place,
it really is just the beginning – Eleanor

1144.34.text:
certainly is a fantastic role model herself
and an inspiration and wonderful I think to

1150.37.text:
have two women Deputy Speakers at the moment
and certainly in the chamber it brings a different

1156.58.text:
tone, although she is quite right, when Dawn
gives you ‘the look’ you certainly sit

1161.80.text:
down and shut up. So on to the main business
of this evening. Our speaker is Helen Langley.

1169.73.text:
She is a historian and a Curator and until
her recent retirement was the manuscript Curator

1174.86.text:
at the Bodleian Library. For many years her
research focussed mainly on the private papers

1180.10.text:
of public figures, including notably Benjamin
Disraeli and the politician and journalist,

1185.50.text:
Honor Balfour, the first president of the
Liberal Club at Oxford. Helen is a contributor

1190.92.text:
to the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography,
including importantly, the entry on Irene

1196.76.text:
Ward. There will be am opportunity at the
end of the lecture for questions but I would

1201.80.text:
just like to hand over this evening to Helen
Langley.

1214.44.text:
Thank you very much. It is a great privilege
and pleasure to deliver the 2015 Speaker’s

1224.60.text:
Advisory Committee on Works of Art International
Women’s Day Lecture, for Westminster was,

1231.61.text:
for over 40 years, Dame Irene’s true home.
Here we see her in later life, her youthful

1238.53.text:
stylishness transmuted into large hats and
capacious handbags.

1242.95.text:
II. Overview
Irene Mary Bewick Ward – still most usually

1247.35.text:
referred to as Dame Irene, despite her later
peerage – was a vigorous champion of the

1252.97.text:
underdog and a diligent constituency MP with
a high national profile. One of the foremost

1259.95.text:
figures in the first wave of women MPs, in
her parliamentary career she outlasted all

1266.05.text:
her contemporaries. She fervidly believed
in the backbencher’s duty to scrutinise

1271.85.text:
and, whenever necessary, harry governments,
including their own.

1277.65.text:
As a backbencher, she successfully introduced
four Private Members’ Bills and campaigned

1283.47.text:
for over 15 years for women’s equal pay.
On her retirement from the Commons in February

1289.97.text:
1974, she was the longest-serving woman MP.
That was overtaken later by Gwyneth Dunwoody,

1297.38.text:
but I think she still holds the record for
introducing four Private Members’ Bills.

1302.82.text:
Much of this, however, is forgotten today.
Partly, this is due to the passage of time,

1309.90.text:
but also, perhaps, because, in her later years,
she became something of a character. The British

1317.87.text:
love eccentrics, and Dame Irene was a larger-than-life
figure. Sometimes, however, in her later years,

1325.00.text:
her political judgment about which issues
to adopt and how to pursue them lacked proportionality

1331.85.text:
and subtlety. One thinks of certain exchanges
with heads of public organisations. She may

1338.65.text:
have revelled in the sobriquet ‘Tory Battleaxe’
and ‘Whitehall Warrior’ and the varying

1344.38.text:
mixes of affection and exasperation she attracted
as ‘Dame Irene being Dame Irene’, but

1351.77.text:
she risked becoming a caricature of herself.
That said, her understanding of the Westminster

1358.27.text:
process remained profound. She knew how to
exploit it to publicise her cause.

1366.37.text:
This afternoon’s lecture revisits some of
the key stages in Dame Irene’s life. It

1372.81.text:
draws mainly on her private papers, those
of the Equal Pay Campaign Committee and printed

1379.22.text:
sources, rather than official records, other
than those quoted in publications. Hopefully,

1386.11.text:
the files in the National Archives contain
a full account of Dame Irene’s exchanges

1391.05.text:
with ministers.
Returning to her papers for this lecture,

1395.86.text:
I was struck by the omissions. There is far
more incoming than outgoing correspondence;

1401.37.text:
there are few copies of the latter. There
is no memoire or detailed journal, other than

1407.03.text:
some from travels. In old age, she gave a
couple of lengthy interviews. When, in the

1412.96.text:
late 1990s, I was researching her life for
Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, I

1418.77.text:
found she had a walk-on part in several books,
the papers of Lady Astor and some organisational

1425.69.text:
archives. Not much more has been written about
her since, so, despite her early high-profile

1432.97.text:
life and later colourful image, there is something
of an elusive quality to Dame Irene. What

1440.11.text:
shines through, though – and it is well
captured in photographs – is enthusiasm

1445.02.text:
for life and for politics.
III. Early Life

1448.62.text:
Dame Irene was renowned for her independence,
tenacity and courage – characteristics which

1455.10.text:
owe much to her experience growing up in what
we might now call genteel poverty, her widowed

1462.61.text:
mother’s small income managed by male in-laws.
Alfred Bewick Ward, who was related to the

1470.18.text:
family that produced the great 18th century
engraver Thomas Bewick, moved from the north

1476.15.text:
to practise as an architect in London, where
he contributed to the designs of the mosaics

1482.55.text:
for the new Westminster Cathedral. He and
Elvina progressed from a flat in St Stephen’s

1488.97.text:
Mansions, where Irene was born, to a house,
33 The Avenue, in Bedford Park. Everything

1495.53.text:
looked set fair but, in 1901, disaster struck:
he became ill and died. Irene was just five

1504.95.text:
years old.
Here we see Irene with her mother, Elvina,

1512.12.text:
and here slightly later and probably after
her father had died – she is not looking

1517.78.text:
too happy. Over the next few years, money
was an issue. I do not know how much Elvina

1525.58.text:
and Irene really had to live on, or the extent
of the Ward brothers’ contribution to the

1530.29.text:
overall amount but, from evidence in Dame
Irene’s private papers – now catalogued

1536.28.text:
and held in the Bodleian Library, Oxford,
it is clear that relations were fraught at

1542.31.text:
Bewick Ward’s will contained precise instructions
for his daughter’s education, but no funds

1547.71.text:
to pay for it. The four Ward uncles rejected
the original choice of local schooling – the

1554.05.text:
charitable Freemasons School – lest it implied
that the family could not afford to pay for

1559.40.text:
Irene’s education. She was, therefore, sent
to Newcastle Church High School for Girls.

1565.04.text:
With one of her uncles paying for their accommodation,
they eventually settled in Gosforth – a

1572.17.text:
suburb of Newcastle. To complicate matters,
the four Ward uncles appear to have disagreed

1578.63.text:
between themselves over the release of funds
to their sister-in-law and niece.

1583.74.text:
In 1916, shortly after coming of age, Irene
threatened to sue her uncle, Percy Ward, an

1591.83.text:
accountant, for non-payment of a relatively
moderate sum – five pounds, four shillings

1596.61.text:
and four pence, which is about £225 in recent
money – and he may have been the most supportive

1604.17.text:
of the four trustees. By 1921, however, when
it was agreed to sell some Thomas Bewick blocks,

1612.38.text:
relations appear to have improved. Although
Irene did not dwell in public on these past

1618.54.text:
experiences, they must have left their mark.
When she wrote to ministers or rose in the

1624.65.text:
House to speak on behalf of widows, pensioners
and others living on small incomes, she knew

1630.61.text:
something of the realities that they faced.
Throughout her career, she was mindful of

1635.67.text:
those whose ‘hard luck had been harder than
my own’.

1639.66.text:
Despite the limited income, Mrs Ward was determined
that Irene should have elocution and dancing

1646.13.text:
lessons. They regularly went to the theatre
– the cheapest seats of course – to see

1650.83.text:
great actors or dancers, like the ballerina
Pavlova, on tour, or hear speakers on contemporary

1657.08.text:
issues, like Mrs Pankhurst on women’s suffrage.
Irene developed a taste for amateur dramatics,

1664.13.text:
performing initially in school productions,
and here we have her, possibly in a Shakespeare

1670.72.text:
production. She played Katherine in The Taming
of the Shrew and Cordelia in King Lear.

1677.07.text:
V. Work
Irene had ambitions to be a writer. In 1906,

1685.62.text:
when she was 11, a couple of her very short
stories about pets had been published in the

1690.97.text:
local press in Aunt Judy’s column. Instead,
she began her paid working life in 1912. Her

1698.74.text:
first actual job may have been as a voluntary
secretary in the local branch of the Royal

1704.10.text:
National Lifeboat Institution. Her first paid
job was as secretary to J T Inskip, a vicar

1710.89.text:
in nearby Jesmond. On her departure in October
1915, he wrote, with some prescience, ‘You

1718.11.text:
have great promise on doing well in life and
I shall watch your career with much interest.’

1724.86.text:
According to a 1931 Daily Mail article by
Lady Alexandra Haig, between 1915 and 1921

1733.31.text:
Irene, keen to enter social service, worked
at the Newcastle Food Office. Judging from

1739.75.text:
a letter she received with her 21st birthday
congratulations in 1916, she was also, for

1746.17.text:
a time, acting as a hospital secretary. Irene
was also working as a Voluntary Aid Detachment

1752.82.text:
(VAD) nurse with the St John Ambulance Brigade
– something she had started to do while

1758.37.text:
still at school – and it was in this role
that she made her first public speech, deputising

1765.27.text:
for her boss, Colonel Claude Palmer, who had
forgotten about the engagement and the supper,

1771.30.text:
and addressing the stretcher-bearers bound
for the front. Here, we see Irene as a VAD,

1777.90.text:
and here she is, roughly the same time, second
left, so she was quite daring.

1785.67.text:
VI. Political Seeds
In an interview with Norman Welch, the journalist,

1790.60.text:
in July 1972, Dame Irene described herself
as a flitter: ‘When I was a girl, I flitted

1797.36.text:
from one interest to another, so, when I got
the sack from Wallsend’ – that is the

1801.61.text:
1945 general election – ‘I was determined
to stick to it, if only to prove to myself

1807.23.text:
and my friends that I could do it. I was also
fascinated by Parliament and obsessed with

1813.09.text:
the urge to fight the north’s cause in Westminster.’
In this same interview, Dame Irene reflected

1819.78.text:
that the political seed may have been sown
as a poll clerk in the 1918 general election.

1826.47.text:
She met and later became good friends with
Sir George Renwick, the Conservative candidate

1831.37.text:
for Newcastle Central, and his wife, Lady
Renwick. The local Conservatives had just

1837.54.text:
embarked on enrolling the newly enfranchised
women over 30 years old. Irene was invited

1843.62.text:
to become the honorary secretary of the Newcastle
Central Conservative Women’s Association.

1849.53.text:
She was also finding her feet as a speaker,
having recently won a speaking competition.

1855.66.text:
Her initial choice of topic had been foreign
affairs but, when she tried this out on Sir

1860.53.text:
Cecil Cochrane, he told her she sounded like
an overstrained curate. Cochrane – an industrialist

1866.55.text:
and colliery-owner who had served as a Liberal
MP for South Shields between 1916 and 1918

1872.02.text:
– is one of the few key male figures in
Dame Irene’s life. Born in 1869, he was

1879.26.text:
16 years older. He spotted her potential while
she was working for him. Somewhat oddly, he

1886.26.text:
and his wife offered to adopt Irene.
VII. Early Election Campaigns

1888.94.text:
1. Wansbeck
It was through visiting his factories and

1891.37.text:
collieries that she acquired the knowledge
of north-eastern industries that informed

1896.21.text:
her first campaign as an MP in 1924, and it
was he who provided a car for her use on the

1903.05.text:
trail around the towns and colliery villages
of the Morpeth constituency. Many years later,

1909.64.text:
a journalist suggested that she had converted
him to her Tory views, but, whether she did

1915.65.text:
or not, he continued to underwrite some of
her political expenses until she entered the

1922.02.text:
House, and for a while after, including providing
a car until 1950. Finances aside, this important

1930.06.text:
friendship lasted until his death in 1960.
Morpeth was Dame Irene’s second attempt

1937.08.text:
at standing for Parliament. In 1923, she had
attracted the notice of the party leadership

1943.25.text:
when she moved her area’s resolution during
the Plymouth conference. Overcome with nerves

1949.39.text:
after a good delivery, she ran back to her
seat, but she did not lose her taste for politics.

1955.94.text:
Quite the opposite, she wanted to stand as
an MP. Convincing constituency parties to

1962.31.text:
accept her, however – an unmarried woman
of 28, not yet eligible to vote – was initially

1968.60.text:
difficult.
An approach in November 1923 to the Wansbeck

1973.03.text:
division was rebuffed by Conservative supporters
living in Whitley Bay. Sir Alexander Leith

1980.13.text:
advised her not to take the rejection personally:
‘From the first to last, the only objection

1986.22.text:
that had been raised is that you are a woman,
and nine out of 10 people at a small private

1990.58.text:
meeting last night did not know you and certainly
had not heard you speak.’ A letter from

1996.72.text:
Conservative Central Office advising her not
to be put off at first attempt was swiftly

2001.90.text:
followed by one from Sir Leigh Maclachlan,
the chief organising agent, promising to find

2008.49.text:
her a constituency, if he could. He admired
her plucky response.

2013.90.text:
Such support from Conservative HQ for woman
candidates was by no means the norm, but it

2019.37.text:
was not an empty gesture. In July 1924, Maclachlan
wrote privately to the chairman of Morpeth

2027.39.text:
constituency party, pledging that Central
Office would pay Irene Ward’s election expenses,

2033.30.text:
if they adopted her as their perspective parliamentary
candidate. The chances of her winning were,

2040.20.text:
of course, nil, but she took her place among
41 women candidates drawn from all parties,

2046.18.text:
up from 15 in 1918.
The constituency centred on Morpeth, historically

2053.00.text:
a market town north of Newcastle. Agriculture,
mining and shipbuilding were the main sources

2059.23.text:
of employment, and it was in the colliery
towns and villages that Dame Irene’s mettle

2064.35.text:
was most tested. Described by the Daily Express
as ‘the girl with the pretty face’, distinguishing

2070.16.text:
her from the two other women candidates standing
in the North East described as ‘an actress’

2077.03.text:
and ‘a widow’, Irene may have appeared
an easy target for the miners angered by their

2082.48.text:
pay and conditions, and most were in no mood
to vote Conservative.

2086.96.text:
In his book Women on the March, John Sleight
cites instances where miners tried to shout

2093.48.text:
her down and threatened to throw her through
the window. In another, chairs were thrown

2099.08.text:
from the balcony. She was more at risk when
she accepted a Blyth communist miner’s challenge

2105.71.text:
to accompany him down a pit. Remember that
Irene is quite tall, and think how small the

2111.87.text:
underground corridors can be. Unknown to her,
he had organised for shots to be fired to

2117.74.text:
dislodge coal, but she did not turn back.
In Morpeth, she fell through a barrel while

2123.58.text:
standing on it, but that may have been an
accident.

2128.15.text:
Not all miners were hostile, and not all her
speaking engagements ended so dramatically.

2134.99.text:
She was invited into some of their homes to
play chess and, as she recalled in the 1977

2141.41.text:
interview, she found her ballroom-dancing
skills useful in the campaign. One anonymous

2147.90.text:
supporter sent this verse to her at a meeting
in Blyth on 24 October, five days ahead of

2154.99.text:
the election: ‘Success to, Miss Irene Ward,
you are bright and brave to risk it. You are

2161.46.text:
educated, spick and span, intelligent and
able. So, come in crowds and send her up to

2167.42.text:
be a pal for Mabel.’
That was Mabel Philipson, the MP for Berwick

2172.66.text:
and former actress. Her election slogan was,
‘By voting the Conservative candidate, you

2179.37.text:
will ward off disaster.’ Her election publicity
embodied the views and interests she would

2186.07.text:
later spend nearly 40 years promoting:
‘I hold progressive views on the needs of

2191.57.text:
social reform in relation to:
Housing, its improvement, and abolition of

2200.68.text:
Equal opportunity for all sections of the
community;

2203.25.text:
Old age pensions – eliminate penalties for
thrift and improve the present state of pensions;

2209.58.text:
Widows’ pensions – widows left with young
children should be provided for.

2213.66.text:
Ex-servicemen – more should be done to forward
their interests.’

2217.18.text:
Remember, this is the early, post-First World
War years.

2221.25.text:
She also highlighted the needs of agriculture,
the grave problems of unemployment in the

2226.50.text:
mining industry, and the importance of trade
revival, safeguarding industries like shipbuilding,

2232.44.text:
and relations with the dominions and colonies.
As expected, however, she lost to the sitting

2238.65.text:
Member, Robert Smillie, a miners’ leader,
but she had won the respect of many, including

2245.31.text:
miners, for her courage and her genuine interest
in their lives. Undeterred by defeat, was

2252.87.text:
Dame Irene really a quitter and a flitter
as she remembers being? She nursed the constituency

2261.54.text:
through to the 1929 general election. During
the intervening years, her value to the Conservatives

2269.48.text:
increased. She was a well regarded speaker,
not just in the North East but further afield.

2277.04.text:
In May 1925, the National Union of Conservative
and Unionist Association (NUCUA) had formed

2281.21.text:
a new parliamentary area committee for Cumberland,
Durham, Northumberland and Westmorland, which

2286.77.text:
would include a woman’s committee, providing
further scope for usefulness. This and other

2292.85.text:
party work are possibly the source of several
unidentified group photographs in Dame Irene’s

2299.55.text:
papers. Here, we have Dame Irene, cloche-hatted,
centre of front row, with a baby on her knee.

2307.39.text:
Who everybody else is I have absolutely no
idea.

2310.45.text:
Speaking engagements also took her overseas.
In October 1925, she visited Canada under

2317.10.text:
the auspices of the Empire parliamentary Association,
with hospitality provided by the National

2322.97.text:
Council of Education. By 1927, her reputation
as a speaker was such that she was invited

2331.10.text:
by the NUCUA Women’s Unionist Organisation
to second the vote of thanks to the Prime

2335.79.text:
Minister at a mass meeting in Albert Hall
in May. This is an undated image, possibly

2342.75.text:
of the event, but definitely featuring Stanley
Baldwin. His reforms of the party’s organisation

2349.11.text:
also made it possible for candidates like
Irene to be adopted.

2353.93.text:
Locally, her repertoire of speeches included
international affairs. In the same year, 1927,

2362.36.text:
she spoke in the Morpeth constituency at a
branch of the League of Nations Union at Guide

2367.39.text:
Post, close by Choppington colliery. In 10
years’ time, she herself would be a government

2373.63.text:
delegate to the League of Nations and win
praise for the work she did there.

2378.22.text:
b. 1929
In 1929, at the so-called ‘Flapper Election’,

2382.91.text:
she was one of 69 women candidates – up
from 41 – put up by the parties, and one

2390.61.text:
of 10 Conservatives. Central Office may have
increased her budget for the campaign. Her

2395.51.text:
electoral address now ran to two pages, illustrated
with reproductions from nine of the Conservative

2404.61.text:
party’s election posters. Her four points
again focused on housing and slum clearance,

2407.04.text:
but this time adding that new houses should
be affordable rents, and large families should

2412.17.text:
not be disqualified. Education and the coal,
shipbuilding and agricultural industries were

2416.95.text:
highlighted. The extension of local-government
health services to poor areas, especially

2424.74.text:
maternity services, was added as priorities.
Only three Conservative women candidates won

2433.48.text:
seats in the election which brought the Labour
party to power, and Irene was not one of them.

2439.02.text:
This is her annotated newspaper cutting with
her defeat. Accepting that Morpeth was unwinnable,

2445.20.text:
she looked for another seat.
Dame Irene has been described as one of the

2450.71.text:
women Conservative candidates who rose through
their work for the party organisation in the

2455.75.text:
wake of 1918’s partial enfranchisement and
the drive to capture women’s votes. Florence

2462.77.text:
Horsburgh, with whom she is often compared,
was another beneficiary. In 1929, Irene was

2469.84.text:
awarded a CBE for her political services – quite
an achievement for a woman in her mid 30s.

2476.56.text:
In April 1930, she was co-opted as a member
of the Central Women’s Advisory Committee

2482.08.text:
for the year. This group of six, chaired by
the Countess of Iveagh, included Mrs Davidson

2488.24.text:
– later Lady Davidson and a future MP – and
Mrs Cheeseman.

2492.14.text:
VIII. Electoral Breakthrough
1. Success in Wallsend

2495.04.text:
1931 would be Irene’s breakthrough year.
Here she is with her volunteer driver, Dolly

2502.84.text:
Sanderson, and the car funded by Sir Cecil.
I think I am right in saying we have one of

2512.14.text:
the horseshoes in her papers – somewhat
faded but still there. One of the 16 women

2518.74.text:
Conservative parliamentary candidates, compared
to 36 for Labour, six for the Liberals and

2527.37.text:
four for other parties, she fought in one
of the only two all-women contests, the other

2533.51.text:
being with Thelma Cazalet and Leah Manning
in Islington.

2538.22.text:
Her Labour opponent in her new constituency
at Wallsend on Tyne was the first ever woman

2543.48.text:
cabinet minister, Margaret Bondfield, the
Minister for Labour. Dame Irene’s papers

2549.56.text:
include two later, undated accounts of her
recollections of the 1931 success. Victory

2556.71.text:
had seemed impossible, as Wallsend had not
returned a Tory since 1910. Margaret Bondfield

2563.02.text:
had been ‘a patronising opponent, never
visualising defeat’. Her confidence that

2569.33.text:
Wallsend was in the bag meant that she campaigned
in other constituencies for Labour. The lesson

2575.73.text:
Irene Ward took from this was never to be
overconfident.

2580.62.text:
Margaret Bondfield had infuriated Irene and
her supporters by ringing up her agent to

2586.18.text:
suggest joint appearances. Irene viewed this
as a move to diminish her stature and create

2592.73.text:
a sense of unreality in what was a serious
contest, so she made what she called a ‘gloves

2598.73.text:
off’ speech to show that she was not an
incidental obstacle to Margaret Bondfield’s

2602.87.text:
success, and then, as she said, ‘the campaign,
of its own accord, came to life.’ After

2609.85.text:
Margaret Bondfield died, Irene Ward paid tribute
to her in the House of Commons in June 1953,

2618.09.text:
describing her as ‘a formidable political
opponent’ – they had battled it out again

2622.56.text:
in the 1935 general election – ‘courageous
as a minister, and she maintained her high

2627.91.text:
office with dignity. She was a power in the
woman’s world.’

2630.52.text:
2. Messages of Congratulation
After Irene’s 1931 success, letters and

2636.58.text:
telegrams of congratulation poured in from
the North East and beyond. Sir Cecil Cochrane

2642.07.text:
was filled with the emotion of the moment.
He would die happy having seen the realisation

2647.76.text:
of his last ambition. Even those who hardly
knew her were moved to write warmly. A letter

2655.10.text:
of congratulation from Helen Atkinson in Hammersmith
described how she had heard her debate in

2660.79.text:
the Women’s Service House with two other
ladies on why you should join my party: ‘As

2665.64.text:
an old suffragette, I took a keen interest
in this debate and could not but conclude

2671.32.text:
your exposition to be much the most masterly.
It showed a breadth of view in dealing with

2676.70.text:
the political situation and a superb marshalling
of facts, which won my admiration.’ She

2682.82.text:
congratulated her ‘and your party also,
as I am sure you are a capital acquisition

2687.95.text:
to it.’
Dame Irene’s undated, possibly post-war

2692.68.text:
account of the declaration of the result and
the cheering crowds which later greeted her

2698.30.text:
is too lengthy to read here but, many years
later, she recalled the impact of overhearing

2704.18.text:
a beggar thank God that she got in. She resolved
to ‘never let these people down’ and to

2710.39.text:
know she would tackle unemployment was a wonderful
feeling, she said. This is Dame Irene’s

2716.75.text:
again undated assessment of the 1931 intake
of women MPs. The unlimited potential of friends

2724.00.text:
and ease with which Conservative women were
absorbed into Parliament was, to her, a ‘delightful

2729.68.text:
memory.’
The new Conservative women never discussed

2732.52.text:
their position as women. There was a tacit,
although never prearranged understanding that

2738.05.text:
entitled them to join the smoke room, though
they never did. She acknowledged, however,

2742.80.text:
that this self-denying audience placed them
at a disadvantage. Reputations, in high circles

2749.13.text:
especially, were made or marred by the smoke
room, ‘An informality which helps to back

2754.47.text:
a course or interest a minister or just generally
be aware of wider developments.’ I think

2760.37.text:
this final comment is really stunning: ‘In
the women’s room, politics had been taboo.’

2765.57.text:
3. Feminist Solidarity
Lady Astor was the first woman to take her

2769.92.text:
seat in Parliament, in 1919, having won it
after her husband very reluctantly vacated

2775.78.text:
it on accession to his father’s title. In
1931, she lost no time in inviting the new

2783.46.text:
women Conservative MPs to a celebratory lunch
in the House of Commons on 10 November. Her

2790.23.text:
congratulatory telegram to Irene included
the sentence, ‘I rejoiced that, at last,

2795.47.text:
we have plenty of the right kind of women.’
Here we have 12 of them. Irene is in the front

2807.19.text:
row, second right. Also in this afternoon’s
narrative, Mary Ada Pickford is to her left,

2814.66.text:
Lady Iveagh sits two seats to her right, Lady
Astor is in the back row, Mavis Tait third

2822.64.text:
left, and Thelma Cazalet centre. Florence
Horsburgh is at the end of the back row.

2828.86.text:
Irene and Lady Astor would go on to work together
in campaigns for equal pay for women and women’s

2834.95.text:
rights in the Indian Constitution. During
Professor – now Sir – Brian Harrison’s

2841.18.text:
interview with Dame Irene in 1977, a copy
of which is now in the Women’s Library,

2847.15.text:
she recalled Lady Astor’s kindness and good
sense of humour, but while she would agree

2852.54.text:
with him that Lady Astor was adept at bringing
women together, she could not endorse her

2857.72.text:
techniques in the House: the constant interruptions,
perhaps forgetting she, herself, had been

2863.75.text:
known at the time to fling questions at ministers
and laugh off the Speaker’s reprimand. She

2871.22.text:
would have preferred Lady Astor not to ring
up Conservative ministers with whom she – Irene

2876.94.text:
– was having difficulties, to tell him what
to do.

2880.77.text:
Professor Harrison – and remember that this
is the 1970s – perhaps hoping to elicit

2884.99.text:
some sense of feminist solidarity, suggested
that Lady Astor’s networking skills – the

2890.80.text:
way she brought women together with other
politicians and reformers – must have been

2895.01.text:
useful but, interestingly, Dame Irene demurred,
recalling a lunch attended by an unusually

2902.22.text:
‘quiet’ George Bernard Shaw.’ This,
at a point in another interview, in which

2908.16.text:
she criticised the dress code for women MPs,
modelled on the black suit and white blouse

2913.68.text:
adopted by Lady Astor to avoid trivial comments
about appearance, offer further insights into

2922.58.text:
There was a strong individualist streak which
rebelled at constraints and manipulations.

2928.85.text:
In the instance of the white blouse, it was
for practical reasons. As she had told Lady

2934.73.text:
Astor, London smog meant a daily change of
blouse, and she might have added, but did

2940.34.text:
not, not all women MPs had the equivalent
resources of St James’s Square and Cliveden.

2946.88.text:
With the power lunches, it was not that Dame
Irene was antisocial; it was more their hybrid

2952.74.text:
and, to her, artificial nature. As she told
Harrison, her mind did not work well in such

2959.85.text:
situations.
In her maiden speech in the House of Commons,

2963.05.text:
in May 1932, during the debate on the Coal
Mines Bill and the closing of uneconomic mines

2969.36.text:
because of surplus output, Irene criticised
the failure to guarantee miners’ wages.

2975.12.text:
As the MP for Wallsend, she would have seen
the consequences at first hand. During the

2981.99.text:
next seven years, Irene Ward would become
one of the two most frequent speakers from

2987.44.text:
the 1931 intake of women MPs, Florence Horsburgh
being the other.

2991.38.text:
IX. Victory in 1935
1. Assiduous Constituency MP

2994.66.text:
Her impressive mastery of what were judged
tough masculine topics – heavy industries

3000.52.text:
like shipbuilding, mining and engineering;
regional unemployment and economic development

3006.04.text:
– though not unique among women MPs, and
her warm, enthusiastic, can-do spirit seen

3012.50.text:
here – this is a jolly Irene; the ships
in the background suggest it is Wallsend.

3018.52.text:
To the right, instilling trust and confidence,
her 1935 general-election photograph, and

3026.29.text:
Irene at Westminster in April 1933, on a smokeless-coal
steam wagon giving a speech in support of

3034.04.text:
miners and English coal. These must surely
have contributed to her victory in the 1935

3040.94.text:
general election. It was a great personal
success against the national trend for her

3046.33.text:
party. Many of her male colleagues in the
north lost their seats and, nationally, the

3051.22.text:
number of Conservative women MPs was reduced
to six.

3054.78.text:
2. Extensive Speaker
Irene Ward, however, was not just an assiduous

3058.57.text:
constituency MP. In the summer of 1936, she
made her second visit to Germany. Her first

3065.13.text:
had been in the autumn of 1932 with a delegation
of women MPs under the auspices of the German

3072.45.text:
Economic and Political Society. The group
had comprised Thelma Cazalet, now probably

3079.67.text:
Irene’s closest parliamentary friend, Florence
Horsburgh, Mary Ada Pickford, and Mrs Helen

3086.14.text:
Brown Shaw. As part of their study of industrial
conditions, the group were also officially

3091.91.text:
welcomed in Berlin.
The 1935 visit to Germany appears to have

3097.15.text:
been part of an extensive solo speaking tour
covering 7,000 miles in four months. From

3104.59.text:
Berlin, she travelled under the British Council
banner to the Baltics and Finland as a sort

3109.87.text:
of goodwill ambassador. She continued on to
France, Hungary, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia.

3118.28.text:
Her main topics were how the British govern,
British women in politics, and self-government

3125.87.text:
At Westminster, she contributed to the 1935
Government of India Bill, with Lady Astor,

3132.33.text:
Mary Ada Pickford and the independent MP Eleanor
Rathbone. Irene Ward piloted several amendments

3139.78.text:
through the Bill’s committee stage to improve
the rights of women under the constitution.

3145.32.text:
Irene had pressed for support through the
Conservative associations and proposed two

3150.49.text:
amendments in the Government’s name.
After Irene’s election success in November,

3156.37.text:
Marjorie Green, Secretary of the National
Council for Equal Citizenship, wrote, ‘We

3161.78.text:
remember with special gratitude your support
of the Indian women’s franchise’, but

3166.32.text:
adding and admitting, ‘We would have liked
to have seen both you and Miss Bondfield in

3171.46.text:
Westminster.’ Irene was also one of a small
cross-party band of women MPs who criticised

3178.60.text:
the national government’s policy towards
the Spanish Civil War. With Eleanor Rathbone,

3184.25.text:
Ellen Wilkinson and Megan Lloyd George, she
served in a committee dealing with the evacuation

3190.74.text:
of children in 1937-8.
Her most significant contribution, however,

3195.16.text:
during her interwar career, and the measure
she remained most proud of in later life,

3201.16.text:
was the 1938 amendment to the 1937 Poor Law
Act. One of eight bills introduced by women

3209.32.text:
between 1919 and 1939, this Private Members’
Bill introduced under the ten-minute rule

3217.37.text:
provided local authorities could pay old-age
pensioners over 65 living in Poor Law Institutions

3222.93.text:
with pocket money of two shillings a week.
That is about £3.70 in recent money.

3229.05.text:
One of the most moving letters in Dame Irene’s
papers is one written and signed, rather shakily,

3234.79.text:
by seven signatories from the Staines Poor
Law Institution near Ashford, Middlesex, in

3240.23.text:
July 1938. ‘It was,’ they wrote, ‘a
God Send to many in here, whose dark clouds

3246.80.text:
overhanging them have now changed to a silver
lining.’ They thanked her for her kindness

3252.52.text:
and interest. ‘We cannot express too much
our gratitude to you.’ This measure was

3258.26.text:
later the basis for paying part of any pension
to hospital patients and similar.

3267.00.text:
During the Second World War, Irene was actively
involved in committees and campaigns addressing

3272.35.text:
women’s employment, inequality and compensation
for injury of civilians, and pay between men

3278.30.text:
and women. She chaired the Women’s Power
Committee established in 1940 after the British

3284.10.text:
Federation for Business and Professional Women
lobbied Lady Astor and others for action on

3289.50.text:
women’s deployment, and this led in to the
campaign for equal pay.

3294.75.text:
She also sat on the offshoot committee linked
to a wider group of women’s organisations.

3300.19.text:
She served on the Women’s Consultative Committee
created by the Minister of Labour, Ernest

3307.19.text:
Bevin, in 1941. For both Irene Ward and Thelma
Cazalet – now Cazalet-Keir; in 1939, she

3313.81.text:
married the writer, David Keir – membership
of the Women’s Power Committee enhanced

3319.44.text:
their influence in the Tory Reform Group,
which supported the 1942 Beveridge Report,

3325.64.text:
and the Conservative Women’s Reform Group.
Irene was in demand as a speaker. Between

3331.65.text:
August 1943 and February 1944, she undertook
the arduous – indeed, perilous – mission

3338.50.text:
to travel to China, India and the Middle East
for the Ministry of Information to explain

3344.73.text:
the British war effort. After France was liberated,
she was dispatched there too. After her defeat

3352.98.text:
in the July 1945 general-election Labour landslide,
the official speaking tours and visits may

3361.92.text:
have helped to ease the temporary exile from
parliamentary life. In Germany and Palestine,

3367.47.text:
she toured camps for displaced persons and,
with Thelma Cazalet-Keir, attended the Nuremberg

3374.94.text:
1. Equal Pay for Women
By 1948, she had been adopted for the constituency

3376.69.text:
of Tynemouth. Ironically, it now included
Whitley Bay, scene of her 1923 dismissal for

3384.12.text:
being ‘just a woman’. Returned to Parliament
in the 1950 general election, defeating the

3391.71.text:
incumbent, Grace Colman, Irene was soon back
in the throes of the Equal Pay for Women campaign.

3398.40.text:
Among her objectives was the formation of
an all-party committee to secure equal pay.

3404.24.text:
She helped draft an amendment to the King’s
Speech to Parliament in March 1950, regretting

3409.66.text:
the absence of mention of equal pay in Government
service. Another of her proposals was an international

3417.81.text:
delegation of women MPs to lobby the International
Labour Organisation on pay in 1951.

3425.99.text:
At Westminster, questioning ministers elicited
details of the extent of equal pay for women

3431.09.text:
civil servants. In May 1952, the House debated
Charles Pannell’s proposal, seconded by

3438.10.text:
Douglas Houghton, in favour of equal pay for
equal work, Houghton’s later motion, in

3444.96.text:
1953, attracting an amendment by Irene. With
other high-profile members of the Equal Pay

3451.01.text:
Campaign Committee, Edith Summerskill and
Barbara Castle, she maintained pressure on

3456.65.text:
the government. Outside Parliament, pressure
was also building up: 1954’s mass meeting

3463.73.text:
and a petition with 80,000 signatures submitted
to coincide with the Commons debate on equal

3469.41.text:
pay.
1955 brought a victory of sorts, but also

3474.86.text:
the disbanding of the Equal Pay Campaign Committee.
The notion of equal pay for women civil servants

3481.42.text:
(non-industrial) was accepted, but implementation
was to be rolled out over seven years. Women

3489.54.text:
teachers had to wait until 1961. Barbara Castle’s
much more comprehensive Equal Pay Act was

3497.93.text:
not achieved until 1970.
In the summer of 1952, Irene took the battle

3504.95.text:
for equal pay to the offices of Parliament
itself, when she championed and eventually

3510.72.text:
won, after a protracted struggle, the case
of the first woman Hansard reporter, Mrs Jean

3517.74.text:
Winder. Appointed in 1944 as a temporary reporter
on £400 per year – the same as the minimum

3524.43.text:
rate for men – the problem arose after the
War, when she had joined the permanent staff

3529.99.text:
and was transferred to a differential scale
but at the same point on the men’s minimum

3536.06.text:
wage.
Irene was particularly incensed by the change

3539.09.text:
in the stance of ministers and others since
the Conservatives had returned to office,

3544.19.text:
reneging on an earlier support for Mrs Winder.
Throughout the rest of 1952 and much of 1953,

3550.84.text:
Irene doggedly persisted, even clashing with
the new Speaker in the process. In August

3559.27.text:
1953, the parliamentary Commissioners finally
agreed that Mrs Winder should be paid the

3564.79.text:
same maximum rate as the men and backdated
to 1 July, her future pay to mirror any revisions

3572.96.text:
in the men’s grade.
Irene’s successful push for women to work

3578.96.text:
in the House of Commons library included walking
through the House carrying a ladder to undermine

3584.79.text:
arguments that had been advanced against the
move: the idea that they could not climb ladders

3589.66.text:
to hand down books. I have included this ladder,
because I think she might approve. From 1955,

3596.73.text:
women were eligible to work in the library.
2. Further Political Contributions

3600.51.text:
The 1950s saw the second of Dame Irene Private
Members Bills passed into legislation. Her

3607.07.text:
1954 Rights of Entry (Gas and Electricity
Boards) Bill protected householders’ rights

3612.31.text:
over access requirements of the nationalised
utilities.

3615.06.text:
3. Women’s Transport Service (WTS)
In 1955, the year she became a Dame of the

3619.60.text:
British Empire, her account of the WTS was
published. Created from the First Aid Nursing

3627.91.text:
Yeomanry – hence the book’s title, F.A.N.Y.
Invicta – the WTS was the parent union for

3634.31.text:
many of the women also recruited into Special
Operations Executive (SOE) during the War.

3641.19.text:
Why Dame Irene wrote the book is not clear.
Perhaps she was encouraged to do so by Mary

3647.15.text:
Baxter Ellis, the head of WTS, or the interest
may have stemmed from her own nursing experience

3653.14.text:
in the First World War or her 1940s work with
the Women’s Consultative Committee, which

3659.18.text:
brought her into contact with the Foreign
Office and the Ministry of Economic Warfare.

3663.99.text:
We may never know the origin of Dame Irene’s
passing reference in one of her many letters

3670.34.text:
from 1956 onwards arguing for an official
history of SOE that she had known many agents,

3677.95.text:
including some who had met their deaths. We
do know, however that the barriers presented

3684.28.text:
to Dame Irene accessing wartime records for
her book informed another of her major campaigns.

3692.69.text:
Here is Dame Irene – a victor of the 1959
general election – ready for her next big

3699.15.text:
campaign. The photograph includes three of
the key figures from the earlier Equal Pay

3704.35.text:
Campaign Committee – Barbara Castle, back
row, fifth from the right; and seated second

3709.73.text:
left, Dr Edith Summerskill; and Dame Irene,
standing, end of the row, holding one of her

3717.50.text:
less capacious handbags. The fourth – Thelma
Cazalet-Keir – was defeated in the 1945

3724.33.text:
general election. Megan Lloyd George – seventh
left, back row – had also promoted women’s

3731.78.text:
issues during the War.
Dame Irene’s belief that her unstinting

3736.21.text:
lobbying convinced Prime Minister Harold Macmillan
to authorise an exploratory study and, ultimately,

3741.76.text:
the commissioning of MRD Foot to write the
official history of SOE in France – finally

3751.14.text:
published nearly a decade later – has since
been reassessed. Research in the National

3757.29.text:
Archives by Dr Christopher Murphy in 2003
revealed that, while the Foreign Office was

3764.09.text:
initially dismissive of her, by 1960 they
began to see advantages in her campaign. An

3771.34.text:
official history would counter the increasing
number of American and Russian accounts which

3776.03.text:
marginalised British involvement with the
European resistance movements, as well as

3780.87.text:
tackle domestic critics, such as Elizabeth
Nicholas and Jean Overton Fuller, who, in

3787.17.text:
the 1950s, published works about SOE operations
and the death of women agents.

3794.39.text:
I am grateful to Oliver House, the cataloguer
of Dame Irene’s papers, for drawing this

3798.99.text:
article to my attention, for if it reduces
her role in the commissioning of the official

3804.99.text:
history, it underscores her ability – most
evident in her campaigning for equal pay – to

3810.54.text:
catch the currents of history. I also cannot
help wondering if the Foreign Office would

3815.83.text:
have been quite so dismissive of Dame Irene
if she had been a man.

3820.48.text:
XI. Later Political Life
In the mid 1950s, Dame Irene required the

3824.81.text:
reputation as ‘an unruly fighter’ (Manchester
Guardian, 1955). It held true for the remainder

3831.44.text:
of her career, reaching its apogee in May
1968, when she disrupted parliamentary business

3838.66.text:
to protest against the guillotine in the Finance
Bill before she could raise issues on the

3843.60.text:
impact in the North East. Banned from the
House for five days, she was escorted from

3852.24.text:
the Chamber. Less dramatically, these were
the years of her appointment to the Public

3854.43.text:
Accounts Committee in 1964, and her third
and fourth Private Members’ Bills: the Nurses

3860.94.text:
Amendment Act 1961 was to do with the training
of assistant nurses, and the Penalties for

3867.21.text:
Drunkenness Act 1962 amending that of 1872.
She continued to campaign for service widows

3875.65.text:
and others on small fixed incomes, and champion,
albeit unsuccessfully, the Carl Rosa touring

3882.28.text:
opera in its battles with the Arts Council.
As always, North East issues, especially housing

3888.57.text:
and industry, claimed her attention. Here
we have Dame Irene on the 1960 parliamentary

3896.69.text:
visit to Russia engaged in conversation, the
female interpreter just out of sight. In 1959,

3904.32.text:
she made a point of remarking that very few
women had ever been sent on parliamentary

3909.51.text:
commission overseas, so I think they took
notice and sent her off to Russia. She came

3914.74.text:
back, of course.
The middle image is from the Commonwealth

3919.15.text:
parliamentary tour to New Zealand and, bottom
left, a weekend guest, probably at Thelma

3924.87.text:
Cazalet-Keir’s house in Kent, and Ted Heath
to her left. While researching the Oxford

3931.97.text:
DNB article I wrote to Baroness Castle for
her recollections of working with Dame Irene

3937.29.text:
on the Equal Pay Campaign, Barbara remembered
Dame Irene as someone ‘easy to respect but

3943.83.text:
difficult to get to know.’
I also wrote to Baroness Thatcher asking if

3949.09.text:
Dame Irene had supported young women MPs rather
as Lady Astor had. I got a really surprisingly

3956.56.text:
letter from Baroness Thatcher, and this is
an extract:

3960.34.text:
Irene made a great impression on all of us
parliamentary candidates at our London meetings,

3965.99.text:
because she was such a tremendous personality.
She was extremely practical in any proposal

3971.63.text:
she put forward and, whenever she got up to
speak, everyone listened. I remember particularly

3979.16.text:
that she regarded herself as an MP for those
who lived on small fixed incomes. Irene was

3986.19.text:
a perfect example of how a Member of Parliament
should represent his or her constituency.

3992.28.text:
XII. Conclusion
How should we remember Dame Irene Ward, Baroness

3998.12.text:
of North Tyneside, today? A doughty Parliamentarian,
certainly; a campaigner against injustice

4005.11.text:
wherever she encountered it; combative, courageous,
impetuous, forceful, passionate, sympathetic;

4012.50.text:
a consistent champion of her North East and
the backbencher’s role, pursuing the latter

4018.73.text:
at the cost of her own wish to be a junior
minister, knowing that she was far too independent

4024.60.text:
to be accepted; sometimes, too, a tad over
the top; in her prime, a magnetic speaker.

4032.73.text:
Throughout her long career, she generated
enthusiasm for the task in hand. She believed

4038.41.text:
that the home should be the centre of a woman’s
life but not its boundaries, though she never

4042.97.text:
made a home for herself. Instead, she poured
her life into her constituencies and into

4048.56.text:
Parliament: a remarkable and a redoubtable
figure.
